title: Socioeconomic factors and suicide rates at large-unit aggregate levels : a comment

abstract: Can socioeconomic factors seemingly explain variation in suicide rates at large-unit aggregate levels only due to an ecological fallacy? This is what Kunce and Anderson (2002) suggest based on fixed-effects estimation of US state suicide rates, in which they find little evidence that socioeconomic factors matter. We demonstrate that this result does not hold true for other large-unit aggregate levels in our analysis of suicide at the cross-national level. We find that many socioeconomic factors have a statistically significant impact. We conclude that sociological and economic theories explaining variation in suicide rates at the large-unit aggregate level with the help of aggregate socioeconomic factors cannot simply be dismissed because of an alleged ecological fallacy

We demonstrate that this result does not hold true for other large-unit aggregate levels in our analysis of suicide at the cross-national level.
